instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> pin 2, 5 are 3.4v, which means the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> entrip will not enable the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> regulator.

However, I cannot figure out for the life of me how <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> drops <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>. Is it internal? So when <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present on pin 2, then <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> will set the output <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> on pin 4 to low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If G2 is high and the output of <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> is not low then check power to pin 1 <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> or it may be dead. <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> simply inverts the signal from pin 2 to 4.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
When <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present on <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>, then <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> is supposed to make <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L_R</SIGNAL> low, which after <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>, should be 0v as <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>.

If <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is high, then <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is not present - because the _L means the signal is asserted when it is "low", in this case, 0v. "<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>" means enable <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> rail, so <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> must be 0v for this to occur.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> will go through <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> which makes it high for <SIGNAL>P5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL> - which has to be 3.3v for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> to be created, and low for <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>, which has to be 0v for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> to be created.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> twice and <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> was still high. <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> had 3.42v on vcc. Shorted out <CAPACITOR>C7942</CAPACITOR> though and the fan spins... Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> must not be high then, there is nothing more to this really. You can remove <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> and see if one of the pins is being pulled high.
